citation.article-title: Shewanella woodyi sp. nov., an exclusively respiratory luminous bacterium isolated from the Alboran Sea.

p.s: Description of Shewanella woodyi sp. nov.
Shewanella woodyi (wood'y.i. M.L. gen. n. woodyi, of Woody, in honor of the American biologist J. Woodland Hastings)
Cells are gram-negative, obligately respiratory, luminescent, marine, nonsporulating rods (0.4 to 1.0 by 1.4 to 2.0 μm), and each cell possess a single, unsheathed, polar flagellum.
The cells use oxygen, nitrate, and nitrite as terminal electron acceptors and possess catalase and oxidase activities.
They grow at 4 to 25°C but not at 30°C.
All strains produce gelatinase, and most strains (27 of 34 strains) produce amylase, but they do not produce lipase, chitinase, or agarase.
They metabolize D-galactose, cellobiose, D-glucuronic acid, acetate, α-ketoglutarate, propionate, succinate, L-alanine, L-threonine, L-leucine, L-serine, and putrescine.
The G+C content of the DNA is 39 mol%.
